reviewText: Finally got a chance to see this after finally finding an All Regions DVD Player that could actually play it. As already mentioned, this is a Region 2 dvd that won't play on standard American dvd players. I tried to play in my regular dvd player, but it wouldn't play it.I will say right-off-the-top that it was great to finally see a real Supremes concert. They were making music before I was actually born, so it's great to at least look back on what I unfortunately missed. This isn't the original Supremes, as already mentioned in other reviews. This concert was in Gebouw, Amsterdam on 4-3-1968. It's suprising short at just over 49 minutes long. Well songs were much shorter in length back then. No musical breaks, and unfortunately, not much real spontaneous action either. It's all nicely structured though, and the women do keep it light and fun at times. Diana, Mary, and Cindy Birdsong do a wonderful job and sound great doing it. The all look great and are quite attractive too. Love the beautiful outfits/dresses they wear. Was suprised at how many showtunes there were, and personally would have liked hearing more Supremes songs. They certainly had enough hits by then. They all apparently loved showtunes too though, and I can't knock them for singing what they love.Playlist includes:1. With A Song In My Heart.2. Stranger In Paradise.3. Wonderfull Wonderfull.4. All My Love.5. Supremes Medley:Stop In The Name Of Love.Come See About Me.My World Is Empty Without You.Baby Love.6. Queen Of The House.7. Love Is Here And Now Your Gone.8. More.9. The Happening10. Michelle/Yesterday11. The Lady Is A Tramp12. In And Out Of Love13. Medley:Throughly Modern MillieSecond Hand RoseMame14. Reflections15. Somewhere (From 'West Side Story)16. You're Nobody Till Somebody Loves You.
Title: N/A

reviewText: We re-watched this DVD last night that I'd purchased in 2007, and I decided to look up what reviews there were. I agree it's great to have it and to see captured the essence of the magic that made The Supremes (not nickpicking here on which incarnation -- simply referring to the group as an entity overall) unique, excellent, prepared and original in what they did and how they presented it.I've read that pop music history has more recently downplayed the significance of The Supremes' success and place in the medium.  I disagree.  I was watching this vid and, again, I realized I was viewing three performers still in just their twenties, and realizing that which they made look so effortless, poised, sophisticated, energetic, mature and flawless meant there was that much more proportionate hard work and rehearsing put into it.  Here, Cindy, Mary and Diana perform professionally far beyond what their then-ages would normally have hinted at...think about all their musical genre peers in the late 1960s, in and out of soul music, at that time..  I was struck how when The Supremes at their height of success were live on TV or in concert, theirs wasn't a girl group presenting a performance: rather, they were a musical act sort of performing like a Broadway show presentation, complete with segue lines, gestures, choreography, costuming, arrangements, and personas all planned and set.  Maybe we need more of that in today's all-too-impromptu (and sometimes undertalented or unprepared) young musical artists.Me, too -- I wish this had been in color -- but that's OK, it lets today's music fans see what made The Supremes in concert SPECIAL.  Every part of their group, performance, and image intertwined and was equally important in making the act successful and unique overall.  Cindy's visual warmness, Mary's beauty and personality, and Diana's talented leading vocals and charisma just blended so well.  They came onstage and were real acting pros: if we only knew, later on, how much that onstage acting ability came into play based on the turmoil that went on in the group back- and off-stage..  ;)As one previous reviewer petitioned, I agree that hopefully -- now, in this "Motown 50" year -- we'll see the suits presently overseeing the Motown label's assets releasing, finally and mercifully for us fans, some boxed set that can present the restored and complete other Supremes specials in which they co-starred such as Anatomy of Pop, TCB and GIT.  Motown worked hard for and earned The Supremes, and in turn they did the same with their success.  We fans, who underlined all this happening for them, ultimately most deserve a positive response to this request of ours!The special played well enough on my Vivo-brand DVD, and I agree that the bonus Flo/Supremes '64 footage was fun.  (Now I know where maybe Diana got the idea for the Boeing 747-distance stageing between her and Lynda and Scherrie for RTL 2000 -- you could've fit a couple of sets of Marvelettes or Velvelettes between Ross and Wilson & Ballard in that '64 stage performance.  :-)
Title: N/A

reviewText: "The Supremes: Greatest Hits - Live in Amsterdam" is a black and white live concert filmed in Amsterdam on March 04, 1968.  Video quality is like that of a VHS tape or an older DVD, grainy, but close-ups are fine.  Audio is O.K.The DVD did not play on my standard American blu-ray player, but it did play on my multi-region DVD player.  This DVD is apparently encoded for European DVD players, (PAL), as it is a product of Holland.This enjoyable concert features Diana Ross, Mary Wilson, and Cindy Birdsong.  They perform some hits and some other songs.  The concert is fairly short and goes by fast.Here is the set list.1. With A Song In My Heart2. Stranger In Paradise3. Wonderful Wonderful4. All My Love5. Medley:Stop! In The Name Of LoveCome See About MeMy World Is Empty Without YouBaby Love6. Queen Of The House7. Love Is Here And Now You're Gone8. More9. The Happening10. Michelle/Yesterday11. The Lady Is A Tramp12. In And Out Of Love13. Medley:Thoroughly Modern MillieSecond Hand RoseMame14. Reflections15. Somewhere (From West Side Story)16. You're Nobody Till Somebody Loves YouThere is also a bonus feature, with three songs from a live concert in Amsterdam on October 14, 1964.  Video is black and white, and a bit more grainy than the first concert.  The concert features Diana Ross, Mary Wilson, and Florence Ballard.1. Baby Love2. When The Lovelight Starts Shining Through His Eyes3. Let Me Go The Right Way
summary: A fast black and white 1968 concert, a bit grainy
Title: N/A

reviewText: When I ordered this DVD last Christmas there was NO warning about it being a Region 2 and therefore incompatible with my DVD player!  This was a big disappointment because there are NO other full concert versions of The Supremes or Diana Ross and the Supremes available for purchase on DVD!  Why can't this be remastered and released on a normal DVD that fans can purchase and enjoy?  There were several concerts of the Supremes that were filmed - including their 2 television specials with the Temptations - "TCB" and "On Broadway" - both in color - that could be released as a boxed set.  Motown/MCA should be ashamed of themselves for sitting on a gold mine and depriving fans of seeing Diana Ross and the Supremes live in concert!
Title: N/A

reviewText: Excellent Concert.  Eventhough it is filmed in black & white, not color.  Also it is Diana Ross & the Supremes, not The Supremes.  False  advertising thru the person selling but even excellent in  black & white.  Shame not in color.  Not the greatest hits, but once again a  excellent concert!!!.I reccommend it to any supremes fan.  99% word for  word as the CD, Diana Ross & The Supremes "Live At London's Talk Of The Town".  Purchase it and  enjoy!!Vince!!.A die  heart  fan!!.from  way  back!!!
